docs.lead_paragraph: THE most worrisome economic tiding for the new year is that health care premiums for employer-based coverage will rise by 10 percent or more in 1999. The startling figure, based on preliminary data from private employers and the program covering Federal employees, is out of line with scant rate increases over the last four years. And it raises the question of whether managed care plans have returned to the days of double-digit rate increases, abandoning their promise to smother medical inflation. There are good reasons to believe the answer is no. The premium increases earlier in the decade were chronic, the symptom of a fee-for-service system lacking financial restraint. Next year's double-digit premium increases appear likely to be temporary. Health costs are rising, but not alarmingly so. It is too early to write off managed care as a fleeting has-been.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Rising health premiums don't mean medical inflation is back.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Paul A. Marks, the president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and one of the city's most important medical figures, said yesterday that he would retire soon after the start of the new year. Dr. Marks gained renown for attracting influential benefactors and patients -- often people who fitted both descriptions -- to the cancer center. He is also credited with raising the center's research profile, which did not have the same stature when Dr. Marks arrived in 1980.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Dec. 26 front-page article does not take into account a more insidious method of reducing access to mental health benefits -- reducing the fees paid to practitioners. Last month two major managed care organizations notified social workers, psychologists and psychiatrists that reimbursement for outpatient services would be reduced by as much as 30 percent. Since fees were already well below the customary and reasonable rates, such reductions are likely to compel the more experienced practitioners to resign from these networks.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To characterize supporters of health care spending accounts as fiendish, as Uwe S. Reinhardt does in ''Popular Tax-Free Health Plans Spark Holiday Rush to Doctors'' (front page, Dec. 25) is ridiculous, as is the contention that this innovation forces repetitive, unpleasant diagnostic tests. Psychotherapy, orthodontia, acupuncture, massage therapy, optometry and other services are recognized as curative, promote well-being and are important remedies in this day of stress-induced and chronic illness. They are also expensive.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Reading ''Insurance Plans Skirt Requirement on Mental Health'' (front page, Dec. 26), I am reminded of the many irate calls I fielded on this subject while working for a health maintenance organization. In one instance a young mother sent in a claim for psychotherapy sessions. After receiving payment at 50 percent of allowed charges for 30 visits and a denial for the subsequent visits, she declared: ''You can't do this! The insurance commissioner will be hearing about this.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Insurance Plans Skirt Requirements on Mental Health'' (front page, Dec. 26): When will American business come to realize that good mental health is good business? Mentally healthy workers are less likely to be absent, involved in accidents or to use their physical health care benefits. Those companies that consider spending on mental health a smart investment that fosters a productive work force should be held out as examples for the rest.
